X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=Z4B5r9PXczmumd9wzGAClmJWq7UYWGEXYHvNXpD5P8a8qXZPL7vP

Hi Peter,

Glad to hear that you are interested in the method, and that you=
've
been able to implement it.

You are correct, the novelty of each indivi=
dual is calculated with
respect to the current population and the archive.
=

Yes, sparseness in the behavioral space around an individual is
equated wi=
th novelty, which is used for the fitness of the individual.

Ideally, nove=
lty would recomputed for each individual in the current
generation after ea=
ch evaluation. In our implementation it is allowed
to get stale for a few e=
valuations (in the same frequency that
individuals are respeciated accordin=
g to rtNEAT). In our experiments,
allowing for a bit staleness did not effe=
ct the results.

Actually, in the scenario you describe, each of the indivi=
duals would
now have a lower novelty, the original individual included. Thi=
s
reflects that the area around these individuals in behavior space is
more=
 dense than it previously was. As more individuals come into a
particular a=
rea, the novelty of all of them drops, and provides
pressure for individual=
s to do something new in order to be seen as novel.

Let me know if you hav=
e any more implementation questions, I'll be
releasing my source based off =
the rtNEAT package in the next few weeks.

Joel 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hello,
> 
> I impl=
emented novelty search and the maze navigation task (it 
> works! :)), but =
I need to ask you about something. 
> 
> So when a new individual is spawne=
d from the population, its novelty is 
> computed based on the domain-speci=
fic distance measure to all other 
> behaviors in the population and the ar=
chive, right. 
> 
> But what about the population itself, should every indi=
vidual there 
> recompute its sparseness on every evaluation, based on the =
new 
> circumstances? 
> 
> I ask this because when I observe the sparsenes=
s (I assume sparseness 
> equals fitness) of the individuals, say one happe=
ns to be in a very 
> sparse area so it receives a high fitness score. But =
then a couple of 
> other individuals come into this area, so it becomes mo=
re dense. But 
> that first individual still has a high fitness score? Is t=
his right? 
> 
> Peter
>
